title: Ticket #6788: Add process family security session
description:
There should be a pre-made security session shared between all daemons in a process tree (e.g. amongst a master and all of its descendants). It would work like the existing session between parent and child daemons, but apply to all daemons in the same family. A daemon whose real uid is different its parent's would not inherit this family session.

When a daemon attempts to connect to another daemon, it first checks whether it has a security session specific to that peer. If it does, then it uses that session, as it does today. Otherwise, it would attempt to use the family security session if both are using the same shared port daemon or, if shared port is disabled, if both are on the same machine. If the family session is rejected, the daemon would fall back to negotiating a new security session.

This would simplify making Condor secure out of the box. No security settings would needed to be set for a single-node Condor setup to be secure, without interfering with admins configuring the security settings themselves.
